"Due to the inactive lifestyle and stressful life, many people are receiving lifestyle diseases such as diabetes, hypertension, etc. The Fit India Movement can encourage people to eat healthy food and maintain physical and mental fitness."

"With high-quality ads and marketing practices, junk food manufacturers are manipulating children to buy their food. This Fit India Movement will make children think about the negative consequences of junk food. As a result, this movement will encourage children to eat healthy food.'

"Some parents put too much stress on children to study. They send their children to classes after school or simply make them sit down to do their homework forgetting the importance of free time to play. This movement has the potential to change people's minds and as a result, they can encourage their children to go out and play."

"This movement has the potential to make more people embrace traditional forms of Indian martial art such as Kathi Samu, Musti Yudha, etc., and traditional dance forms as well as healthy Indian snacks. And as a by-product, this may result in the creation of some jobs.'
"The motivation to maintain fitness must begin in childhood. But in India, many schools lack playgrounds. The lack of playgrounds can push children into inactive lifestyles."

"The ‘Indian Movement’ may not reach people below the poverty line. In order to maintain a healthy lifestyle, both physical activity and nutritious foods are necessary. But in India, many people are still malnourished and some people do not have access to drinking water. Therefore, without solving the problem of poverty and lack of access to affordable nutritious food, a section of the population of India will not be able to take advantage of this movement.'

"Some people are already focusing on physical fitness. We can see this with the growing number of fitness startups. But that is a small proportion of people. In general, many people want to maintain an active lifestyle, but all they need is a little encouragement. Therefore, this movement constantly reminds people to focus on fitness goals just as Swachh Bharat reminds us of the importance of keeping our environment clean."

"Since the invention of machines, the value of workers has been declining. They are made to work to support the machines. As a result, the work revolves around machines and not humans. Workers are forced to work continuously with the machine. "

"People are now getting involved in curricane and cyberne. Hiding behind devices is giving them the courage to harass other people, which they may not do face to face. This is the deterioration of moral values.'

"Some companies are building strategies to use their applications for longer, to keep us addicted to their applications and devices so they can show us ads. And they can also use our data to manipulate our decisions for their profits. These strategies are turning people into fair targets.'

"Industrialization increased working hours. Workers are facing inhumane conditions. Humans cannot work and focus continuously like machines. Soon to this day, we have technological devices to check how many hours we actually work. Some companies want to be connected 24 hours a day through emails and messages. This makes people feel less humane.'

"Our decision-making skills are also being affected, as we are now asking search engines to know what is best. We rely on the Internet knowledge base even in the offices to finish the work by hand. This affects cognitive abilities (thinking, reading, learning, remembering and reasoning), which is an essential quality of human beings."

"Many face-to-face communications are also replaced by virtual interactions. Many people now live in virtual homes, which is the smart phone. As the need to talk to one another is diminishing, the ability to communicate with one another, which is a basic quality of living beings, is diminishing.'

"We are increasingly dependent on the technological devices that guide us. For example, we keep reminders on smart phones and google the questions to get answers. We are outsourcing activities that require technology intelligence. Thinking, remembering and analyzing are essential qualities of human beings. Too much reliance on technology is making us less human.'

"Using technology, people are maintaining and improving relationships with their friends, family and relatives. Many people also connect with each other to help the needy and to inspire each other. So now we have better tools to build human connections."

Technology allows us to work from home. This service is helping employers to be more understanding with employees. Many companies are now adding elements to work culture with the help of technology to make employees feel important.

"This draft law gives exclusive competence to the National Research Agency (NIA). NIA may take any person under its custody under the UAPA without prior permission from the state government. This is against federalism, which is guaranteed by the constitution of India.'

"The organisations labelled as terrorist organisations and individuals as terrorists are very different. For example, in 2016 alone, 67 per cent of cases ended in acquittal, which means that they are probably innocent.'

"If someone is registered under the UAPA, the burden of proving their innocence falls on them. This new amendment is allowing the government to confiscate their property. How, then, will they pay the legal costs of proving their innocence, if they are falsely accused?'

"This will give more police powers to the central government. The designation of persons as terrorists can be misused. For example, several civil activists have recently been called Urban Naxals. "There is a growing threat of lone wolf terrorism. Lone wolf terrorists have no association with terrorist organisations, but they carry out terrorist attacks alone. This new amendment to the UAPA has the potential to curb lone wolf terrorism.'

"The Indians as a whole see educational institutions as work machines, we hope to go into unemployment and get out of work. " Although we have been establishing institutes at national level for the last 40 years, we have not been investing to maintain their standards. Funds are needed for quality education. Today, no problem has a single solution and no new technology is related to a single discipline. We need multiple contributions from multiple disciplines and our institutes have failed to do so.

"Indian students act brilliantly when they go to different countries in the field of research. It means that we do not lack talent, we lack infrastructure and a healthy environment for our acute minds.'

"We have not been paying our teachers on the scale of what their counterparts earn in other countries. As a result, people are reluctant to see education as a career. Nor have we succeeded in attracting successful foreign faculties to our institutes.'

"Achieving excellence in everything takes time. Through graduation, students gain so much knowledge in the relevant field. It is therefore easier for employers to train these students for industrial requirements.'

"Even if someone has a degree in IT, they have to learn a lot to get into IT work, because there is a gap between industrial standards and the skills taught in engineering universities. Therefore, as the learning curve will be there even for IT students, students of non-IT origin can also learn these things and can get into IT jobs."

"The number of IT jobs is growing at a rapid pace due to the technological revolution. There will therefore be more jobs in the field of information technology. And if recruiters are very strict about the degree, they can lose a large group of talent, who are from a non-IT fund."

"If a non-IT student decides to embark on a career in the IT field, efforts at graduation will be in vain."

"Although the new programming languages are replacing the old ones, the basic concepts are the same for almost all programming languages. Therefore, whoever has a degree in coding will have an advantage over the student of a non-IT fund.'

"People change careers even after working in a field for several years because our interests change. Therefore, when someone can do this while having so many personal responsibilities, it is much easier for young people to learn a new skill. "

"The variable remuneration definitely increases the productivity of employees. High performers feel well compensated and rewarded for their efforts, while low performers also feel motivated to improve."

"In variable remuneration schemes, employees feel satisfied and motivated with their work. They feel an active part of the organisation, the organisation recognises them as part of its growth and values their efforts."
"Flexible pay helps retain valuable employees. This helps to retain good talent for long periods of time and thus to spend less on recruiting new talent. This provides stability to the organisation.'

" It has been shown that it is difficult to retain employees in times of scarcity when they are in variable pay systems. The workers who receive commissions do well when the business is good, but they do badly when the business is bad. In times of slow business, even the main sellers may find it difficult to make enough sales to earn a decent living. If the market is slow and incumbents cannot earn enough, they can look for other employment opportunities. In times of scarcity, fixed wages can be more effective in preventing employees from going for other opportunities.'

"Variable remuneration can lead to unhealthy competition between employees. They are becoming less willing to help each other. The team's cooperation can be adversely affected. In the long term, relations between colleagues can become bitter. Whereas, under fixed remuneration schemes, employees can maintain cordial relations in the office.'

"For the most part, sales jobs have a variable component. This could negatively affect the employee's attitude towards customers. They can force customers irrationally just to make profits for themselves. They could exaggerate the price to customers just to make more profits. While a fixed-wage employee would maintain healthy and positive relationships with clients, achieving the right balance in their approach."

"The enormous data we produce every day is analyzed and fed into our devices through algorithms that end up giving gadgets more and more control over our lives. We can feel that we receive all these services free of charge, but they come at the expense of our precious time and attention."

"With all the data and algorithms our applications and gadgets, without our conscious knowledge, are making decisions for us. Decision-making is (was) one of the qualities that made human beings different from others"

"The refugees are forcibly displaced.
